Posts.Title: Mentally Preparing for Single Mastectomy aab CrunchyPoodleMama

Posts.Content: aab wrote: I'm in my early 30s and am scheduled for a single mastectomy (left) on 1/5/2011 with a tissue expander for later reconstruction.  I've completed 6 months of chemo already and am certainly glad to have that part behind me.  While I've read a lot on these forums about what to physically expect and prepare for, I'd also like to get some advice from you all that have been through it on how to handle the emotional, mental, and psychological impact of losing a breast. While I would honestly categorize my level of apprehension as average or normal, I'm sure it's impossible to truly predict how I'll feel after surgery.  So I'm reaching out to you who have been through it to try to help prepare myself for the range of emotions that I might expect afterwards.  Any advice, thoughts, or experiences you can share would be most appreciated! Dx 6/6/2010, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: aab wrote: I had a mastectomy and a sentinel node biopsy last week. The node was positive and so the surgeon performed an axillary node dissection. I will receive my pathology report this upcoming week. I have already had chemo, finished in December. I am also scheduled for radiation. Having already gone through chemo, is there a chance I will have to again since my lymph node was positive? I'm not sure if they typically remove the nodes and hope radiation gets any remaining cells. I was just curious about the potential of having to go through chemo again. Any thoughts are appreciated! Posts.Title: Diagnosed with IDC stage IIa aab paigelise

Posts.Content: aab wrote: I recently had a mastectomy and an axillary lymph node dissection. My tumor was removed and only one out of fifteen lymph nodes were positive. Neoadjuvent chemotherapy was successful at reducing the tumor size. My tumor was sent to pathology for additional testing because both invasive and non-invasive cells were found. I was told 10% of my tumor was made up of ER Positive cells. I will most likely have to take tomoxifen once I complete radiation. I am a bit confused by this because all this time I thought I had triple negative breast cancer, both hormone negative. What/ how can a tumor have both types of cells? My oncologist is wonderful and I know she will do a great job at provided the clarity I need but thought I could get some insight before I meet with her. Your help is appreciated!
